Comments and notes to 太平經 for translation .

p.seg: "These (three) [orders of] longevity" are defined above as lasting 60 (inferior), 80 (average) and 120 years (superior).
On the "three [orders of] longevity" 三壽, see comment above.
The seven regulators 七政 are the sun, the moon, and the five planets, or the seven stars of the Dipper; the three luminaries 三光 are the sun, moon and stars.
The ruler is also likened to the Pole Star in the Analects 論語, 2.1.
Observed from the surface of the earth at night, the starry sky appears to rotate around the Pole Star.
S and B refer to the sequence of the 10 Heavenly Stems and 12 Earthly Branches respectively.

(1) "Initial novena" 初九 here designates the first of the six months of Yang growth. In the terminology of the Book of Changes 易經 and related texts, it is the name of the first line at the bottom of a hexagram, when the line is Yang 陽 (unbroken). (2) "The sun begins to return" 日始還: the duration of daytime begins to increase again, after the winter solstice.
The "gate of heaven" 天門 is the North-West, where is located the trigram Qian 乾 in the post-celestial configuration.
"Yin and Yang are set in motion" 陰陽運: Yin declines while Yang grows.

"Second novena" 九二 and "third novena" 九三 here refer to the second and third months of Yang growth. In 易經 terminology, the expressions designate the second and third lines of a hexagram—starting from the bottom line—when these lines are Yang (unbroken).
"[T]he kidneys": for 賢, read 腎.
"Proliferation": tentatively reading 蕃 for 藩.
"Cerulean light", "grand darkness", the kidneys, and the heavenly stems Ren (S9) and Gui (S10) all correspond to North and the Water agent.
The twelfth and first earthly branches, which follow one another as the duodecimal cycle ends and begins again, symbolize Yang appearing again within Yin.
The "five essences" 五精 are presumably related to the five viscera.
According to modern Chinese commentaries, this verse would refer either to a twelve-fold division of the body, or to the circulation of pneuma in accordance with the twelve months of a year.

The Dunhuang manuscript Stein 4226 suggests that this passage is the abridged rendition of now-lost chapter 79, whose title was "Illustration of the Embryo in the Womb, Yin and Yang" 胞胎隂陽啚 (圖) and presumably included visual materials. The "images" (or portraits) 像 may have been those of divinities (or emblems) corresponding to the 12 months or earthly branches, to be drawn by the adept during the practice, probably as support for visualisation.
